column5: writing code style and best practices
We will cover the highlights and common problems from today's topics
You will work with your own dataset to try out building code using some of the tools that you have learned
column9:
Set up an R project! 
1) Initiate a new script. 
2) Use good etiquette to organize and name things 
3)Import your data. 
4) View your data and make note of columns/rows you don't need. Also note columns/rows that you may need to create (don't worry about trying to do this yet - we'll cover it tomorrow).  

Want more practice? Try this:
1) What is the difference between Run and Source? 
2) What does the magic wand do to your formatting? 
3) What happens when you start introducing quotes? 
4) What other sections do you think you'll need in your script?

column5: Share what you attempted  to code

column9: https://ourcodingclub.github.io/tutorials/modelling/, Distributions & linear models. 1)*optional* continue on to 'More practice: another model' 2) stop at Part 4 - no need to do GLM section*

column5: We will cover the highlights and common problems from today's topics
You will work with your own dataset to try out building code using some of the tools that you have learned
column9: Tidy your imported data (answer your questions from yesterday). Change the variable data types as needed (Think about using clear variables). Explore/summarize your data Create a basic linear model. Want more practice? Try this: 1) Use hist() and other base R plot commands (e.g., plot()) to investigate your data distribution. 2) Complete sections on glms and validating model assumptions. 3) Apply other (non-parametric, if appropriate) tests to your data

column4: Q&A goals and examples of data visualization

column5: We will cover the highlights and common problems from today's topics
You will work with your own dataset to try out building code using some of the tools that you have learned
column9: Decide on type of plot for your data. Create a plot with labels and colors. Initiate a new Rmarkdown file Include your plot, a table of your model output, and explanatory text in the Rmd file Include an inline use of R in your text. Want more? Try  this: 1) Make it pretty! Work with custom themes and colors 2) Try to apply a facet wrap (multiple panels) 3) Try to export your .Rmd as a PDF, word document, or presentation and adjust formatting.
